SPRITEs-NVDA Add-on Tutorial

Step-by-step tutorial on how to use the SPRITEs Add-on with NVDA, including keyboard navigation and keyword search.

Consent for Improving Interaction Study

Thank you for visiting the SPRITEs tutorial website! SPRITEs is an NVDA addon that introduces a new way to navigate tables using your keyboard, on google chrome. We wanted to give you some information before you continue to use this website. The purpose of this website is to provide information or to host a tutorial to teach you to use our improved interaction techniques. With your consent, we would like to gather basic usage information like time spent on each webpage and the buttons or links that you click on or activate as you use this website. Please note that this aggregated information can not be used to identify you and will be stored securely in a separate location from any data you may explicitly provide in this website. Aggregated data received from this website may be used to improve our tools and provide better experiences, and may also be used in scientific publications or blogs to communicate the efficacy of the interaction techniques we develop. Please note that you can continue to use the website even if you chose to not provide the data mentioned above, but functionality may be limited in some cases. This addon, and the tutorial are research products and we appreciate any feedback via this google form or issues and feature requests via GitHub. Please choose an option below to continue.

*Please select one of the options above.

Pilot Study Table

You are given a weekly schedule for a college-level calculus class, and your task is to use SPRITEs table navigation to find out some important information from the schedule.

  1. You want to figure out which weeks have exams so you could prepare for it ahead of time. How would you locate the weeks with exams?
  2. There are some weeks in the quarter where there are no classes on Mondays. How would you find those weeks?
  3. You want to review the concept of improper integrals and need to figure out which sections of textbooks might be relevant. How would you go about doing that?
Week Exam Archive Topics and Textbook Sections
1 Antiderivatives; Areas and Riemann Sums; Definite Integrals. (in Stewart: Sec. 4.9, 5.1, 5.2)
2 The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus; Indefinite Integrals & Total vs Net Change; The Technique of Substitution. (Sec. 5.3, 5.4, 5.5)
3 No class on Monday. Applications: Areas between Curves, Volumes By Slicing, and the Disks/Washers method. (Sec. 6.1, 6.2)
4 Exam #1 Archive Applications: Volumes of Solids of Revolutions via Shells; Review; Exam #1; Applications: Work. (Sec. 6.3, 6.4)
5 Applications: Work; Average Value of a Function; Techniques of Integration: Integration by Parts, Products of Trig Functions (Sec. 6.4/6.5; 7.1, 7.2)
6 More Techniques: Trigonometric Substitution, Partial Fractions, Strategies of Integration (Sec. 7.3, 7.4, 7.5)
7 Exam #2 Archive No class on Monday. Review; Exam #2; Approximation of Integrals; (Sec. 7.7)
8 Improper Integrals; Applications: Arc Length of a Curve & Center of Mass (Sec. 7.8, 8.1; part of 8.3)
9 Intro to Diff Eqs; Solving Separable Differentiable Equations; Various Applications of Diff. Eqs. (Sec. 9.1, 9.3, 9.4)
10 Final Exam Archive More Applications of Diff. Eqs.; Review; Exam #3 (Sec. 3.8; 9.4)
